page.title: 14ROUNDHOUSE - MARSTON MEYSEY
page.content: A {Roundhouse,}built as one of five watchman's round cottages in 1790 along the {Severn and Thames Canal,} stands in isolation alongside a humpbacked brick bridge in{Marston {Meysey.}This three storey building like a tower is now derelict. The ground floor was used as a stable reached only from outside. The first floor was a single living room and the top floor was a bedroom. The rooms have an internal diameter of 16 feet by 10 feet, slightly flattened to accommodate the kitchen range and fireplaces. It is constructed of stone covered with plaster and stucco. The parapet at the top enclosed a rain water cistern: where rafters sloped down to the centre to a leaden bowl. The{Roundhouse,}as with some toll houses, gave excellent views up and down the canal.
